intro: Rhus tepetate, commonly known as the Mexican sumac, is a deciduous shrub or small tree native to Mexico and parts of Central America. It belongs to the Anacardiaceae family, which includes other plants like poison ivy and cashew. The plant is characterized by its compound leaves, which are often arranged in pairs along the stems. Its small, yellowish-green flowers appear in clusters and are followed by red, fuzzy berries that mature in the fall. Rhus tepetate is often found in dry, rocky soils and is adapted to arid and semi-arid environments.
